ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I came to better understand issues of international cooperation in war, trade, treaties, and international institutions
causes of war and various theories of peace, state formation, international trade, liberal international order, rise of populism
I developed knowledge about theories of war, human rights treaties, international organizations, trade, and global development.

Basic workings of international relations, including international agreements, theories of war, trade and political economy, and domestic influences on international behavior -- taught with great examples. I also wrote a really interesting paper which applied a lot of the international relations-thinking.
why countries fight wars, international relations
I learned a lot about international relations and everything that goes into that.
IR, war, trade, social science/research
I learned the basics of the international system on topics ranging from trade to wars. I also learned the process of writing a research paper.
I learned about collective action problems, what causes war, and the forces behind international trade.
I learned about theories and facts regarding International Relations, conflict, trade, state formation, economic aid, and other related topics.
Causes of war, game theory in international relations, role of international institutions in the fields of human rights, trade, and diplomacy
learned a lot of the way we discuss international relations. As it was an intro class, a lot of information was very much surface level.
A comprehensive overview of various topics related to IR. There's definitely an emphasizes on the political economy aspect, but with a lot of political philosophy throughout as well
It gave a general overview of international relations as a political science field.
Overview of topics in political science/international relations -- state formation, intl agreements, war, civil conflict, terrorism, intl development, intl economics.
I struggled to enjoy this course and learn new things. The lectures were dense with game theory concepts, which I did not expect in an introductory course on international relations.
Learned about international relations.

I learned about the role of institutions, diplomacy, costs and benefits, and norms in the international arena by reading case studies, applying game theory, and using economics. Above all, this course gave me a greater understanding of why countries go to war and how to prevent (and measure) conflict.
I gained a broader understanding of international relations that I did not have previously.

I learned a lot about international relations and diplomacy, and felt that my understanding of how countries negotiate and bargain with each other was greatly deepened.  I also developed my research/analytical skills through writing the final paper.
Gained a good understanding about the fundamentals of trade, war, treaties, and international aid.
I learned general international relations principles in a variety of subjects. Very broad overview of different aspects of the field, personally my favorite was the civil war unit!

Ive developed a much broader understanding of international relations and the global world in general 
.
We learned about many important theories and views on international issues
basics of IR, game theory

The course covered topics such as war, global institutions and finances, and trade policy. I gained insights into why states develop the foreign policy that they do - whether that be in regard to trade or conflict. I also learned more about how domestic politics can influence global decisions.
Introductory stuff about international relations, nothing too specific. A bunch of theoretical frameworks and soft skills.
I learned a lot about the fundamentals of international relations.
I learned about the fundamental principles of international relations and how they apply to world matters.
I learned the broad basic scopes and perspectives of IR, learned a lot about research in the social sciences, and learned to write a social sciences research paper.
A great broad overview of some basic political science theories and models.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course provides a great introduction to the topic of IR but doesnt dive especially deep into any area (went I wouldve liked to study it even more). That is likely an inherent issue with intro classes and I certainly wouldnt fault the instructor or syllabus.

My only criticism of the class is that the readings were simply too excessive. I ended up having to skip the majority of them, which I very much regret because the ones that I was able to read were incredibly interesting. But the sheet amount of reading expected was much too high for an introductory class. Beyond that, my experience was excellent. I enjoyed the class, the professor and my TF were both great, and overall I think it was well-organized and expertly conducted.

so many assignments that are needlessly long, felt like we had a quiz every other week that took up a lot of time. Professor Scheve also spoke very very quickly during lecture and it was often difficult to keep up

STRENGTHS: Professor Scheve is very knowledgable, TAs are incredibly helpful, subject matter is very thorough, readings are interesting

WEAKNESSES: Felt like we focused on war for a long time, workload was a lot toward the end, lectures could be a bit boring with just the powerpoint slides but it was Zoom so that is to be expected

Strengths: The course moves quickly with lots of information and readings, which are usually interesting. Professor Scheve is a great lecturer and is really interested in the material. The content is really interesting, especially on international trade. They ask for a lot of feedback and actually use it, which is cool. I thought the course was going to focus more on the isms, but it didn't, which ended up being great. I am also not a very quantitative person, and the class is definitely more quantitive than I thought it would be, but it ended up being really interesting as well.

Weaknesses: The readings can be quite long and technical, and sometimes it didn't feel like they were aligning with the lectures very well towards the beginning of class, but that improved towards the end. The course does move very fast.
the readings were very long and it wasn't always clear what we were supposed to be getting from them. this could be improved by shortening the lengths of the readings.

Strengths: The class went over a lot of material, if that's what you're looking for

Weaknesses: This course is very dense, and the sections often went over new material rather than discussing the lecture explicitly (many section meetings had their own readings)
Nothing to improve, good course
This course was very interesting and well-taught, but I often felt that there were too many readings for us to actually absorb any of the information.
The topics were very interesting and the final paper was very engaging. One weakness is that the pace of lectures often felt too fast.

Strengths include organization, engaging lectures, clear slides, and a manageable workload. There are not a lot of weaknesses. Perhaps practice questions to help review for the exams would be helpful.
I wish we had received more guidance on the structure of the final paper. The expectations were very unclear.

The readings were not as engaging as we didn't speak about them in class and it felt like they were only there for the midterm. Moreover, having a quiz, a midterm and a paper due back to back was overwhelming towards the end. The display and teaching of the material was excellent however and I really enjoyed it!

This course goes into way too much detail about complex topics for an "intro" PLSC class. At times, the class felt like an upper-level macro or game theory course, and we covered topics like war using counterintuitive methods that very few of us had even heard of before. Exams are open-book and open-note, but they often tasked us with finding minute details in long, advanced readings that we hadn't covered that much. This made it very stressful and hard to tell exactly how each of us was doing in the class. 
I also felt that we didn't get enough guidance on the final paper (or, in general, how to read and write political science research papers).

I did not enjoy this course. The lectures were loaded with words which made it difficult to take notes and feel engaged at the same time. The concepts were also more technical and we did not explore any case studies in depth.
A lot of topics but not a lot of information about them.

I thought that the professor was very engaging and really enjoyed my sections. However, I found the lectures to be very long and filled with too many details, so they were difficult to follow. I also felt that a large amount of reading was assigned, but it was repetitive and often irrelevant, and even doing all of the reading, grading on assessments was so harsh that I did not do well.

The course gives a very good comprehensive overview of the field to IR for students who may not have taken a similar course before, but moves very quickly and may be harder to follow for students not considering a major in a related field (e.g. Political Science, Global Affairs or EP&E).  It may be worthwhile to slow down the material slightly and spend more time on important conceptual topics being introduced (e.g. tragedy of the commons, democratic peace theory) to ensure all students can follow the course and remain engaged in the material.
Very interesting content, not always taught in a way that was accessible to students who were new to the subject.

Strengths: Class is interesting and tests are comprehensive. Sections are intriguing.

Weaknesses: Class materials are somewhat boring.
It could be a mit more discussion based, but I can see how this was not very possible because of COVID.
My ability to synthesize thoughts about international politics from a variety of sources.
The discussion sections and lectures are generally very engaging
Strengths: the variety of topics covered, the contemporary examples of topics covered in the course. Weaknesses: the material was covered too quickly at times.
Great professor and TFs. They were accommodating towards COVID and the virtual format.
Less readings and more interactive assignments. I would rather do problem sets than have hundreds of pages assigned that never get discussed.

Strengths - the content was very interesting
Weaknesses - the sections were rigidly structured and didn't allow for natural conversation

I wouldve liked a little bit more freedom with regards to essay topics throughout the year. I found that I was able to express my knowledge of topics discussed in class better while writing essays as opposed to taking exams.

A strong point of this course were the quizzes and the sections because a lot of learning was reiterated and cemented in section and the quizzes were a good indicator of progress. A weakness of the course was that a lot of content was covered in each lecture; it wasn't necessarily an excessively fast class as a whole, but there wasn't always time to finish the lecture every day.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I particularly enjoyed the recorded lectures. Breakout rooms and discussion sections were sometimes lacking in student participation
great format! live lectures with the option to watch the recording on canvas!
I liked the virtual civil war game
I really appreciated having the lectures recorded so I could review later.
I really enjoyed the quizzes that had multiple attempts because I felt like I could actually learn the material instead of having to worry about a grade.
Nothing much!
The zoom lectures were as good as they could be. The professor attempted to use breakout rooms but they just felt like busywork.
No weaknesses. Recorded=live lectures were great.
I wish there were more office hours with Prof. Scheve and more time in class devoted to going over the readings.
The live virtual lectures were not terrible, but the powerpoint slides were not conducive to learning the material.
I thought that the format worked. I enjoyed the breakout rooms during section, but echoing my other comment, felt that the lectures were a bit rushed and could have been improved.

Professor Scheve adjusted his teaching method due to the pandemic and made more exams take-home and open-book with questions that would require more time and thought to answer, but this was very helpful, especially considering that many members of the class took the course asynchronously/in different time zones.  The final paper (rather than just a final exam) was also a good test of knowledge acquired in the class in a less time-constrained manner.  Professor Scheve also hosted office hours every Friday to help ensure students understood the contents of the course and felt prepared for midterms and the final paper.
I would require students to keep their cameras on to increase participation.
Lectures and activities were all successful. The polls were not so successful.
The interactive break-out rooms are very helpful and helps us grasp the concepts better
Successes: breakout rooms for discussion. Could be improved: more structured discussion sections.
I liked the sections and virtual lectures, but too many readings.
I think the sections could have been improved
Not much could have been better.
Section and in-class polls worked very well, breakout rooms did not.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if you are new to the field and want to gain frameworks to study international cooperation in trade, organization, war, etc. It seems like a great springboard to further study IR  though it is perhaps not as engaging as a more specialized/advanced course.

This is a very interesting class, and I would certainly recommend it to a fellow student. The only warning I would give is that the amount of reading expected is quite high. So be prepared to either read a lot or employ discretion as to which readings can afford to be skipped. Beyond that, the class was excellent and I hope that students in the future will enjoy it as much as I have.
I wouldn't really recommend this class. You honestly don't really come out feeling like you have learned much of anything and will just be stressed about the many quizzes and midterms

I would if you want a general description of the theoretical models underlying major aspects of international relations. We talked about models of war and trade alongside the role of international treaties.

Yes! It's a lot of reading, and the lectures have a lot of material, but it's such an interesting and useful class. To be able to think on basic theoretical levels and understand the empirical work behind certain IR claims is really incredibly useful in a practical way. You'll find yourself thinking about countries (in the news, for example) in terms of coordination, thinking about how domestic institutions are affecting the government's response; and trying to identify issues in wars on much more simpler IR terms (indivisibility, regime change, policy) that actually make thinking about conflict easier and better. I really enjoyed the parts of the class that focused on trade, and thinking about that as well with IR language helps a lot. Prof Scheve is a great lecturer and very much wants to help you do well. I certainly did not understand everything or score perfectly on assignments and exams, but I learned a lot that I'll be able to use going forward even as a non GA/poli sci major.

not really, unless they're especially interested in studying very specific models of international relations - I took this class expecting a general overview of theories of international relations, perhaps with a more historical approach, but it's very game-theoretic and model-heavy in a way that made me dislike the course
yes! good way for people who are interested in international relations to learn material

If you really want to learn about International relations, then sure. Just know that the class is very dense and requires a lot of theoretical understanding.
If you're just taking it because you're a political science major and it's an intro class that you can take, then no.
Yes, esp those interested in majoring in Global Affairs or pursuing foreign/international policy as a career
Yes!

I would. Although it was a lot of work, you gain an understanding for how international institutions function, as well as their shortcomings. I think this is a great introductory course for anyone looking towards learning about global affairs!
Yes but be prepared to do a lot of reading. The topics are interesting and the professor is very nice, but only take this if you can handle a lot of readings that dont always feel necessary.
Yes! This is a great class for students interested in international relations or the poli sci. Very interesting.
Definetely would recommend to any students who are considering political science or international relations
Absolutely if you're looking to learn more about a wide array of topics within IR/political economy.
No- take a different course if you're interested in PLSC or looking for a social science credit.

Not really. The lectures did not cover all of the material in depth and the reading load was too much every week, given that we had both lecture readings and section readings to complete per week. I also did not like that the lecture readings were never discussed in section.
If they are interested to learn about international relations.

I would not necessarily recommend this course because I did not feel like I got a full foundation of understanding international relations. There was a lot of reading and assessments, and I did not necessarily find it interesting unfortunately.

Yes, particularly for students interested in majoring in Political Science or Global Affairs, since it provides an in-depth introduction to the field of IR.  However, it might be slightly less engaging for students not already familiar with many basic concepts in the area of political science.

Yes! Do take this course, Ken is really passionate about this stuff and if you're at all interested in learning about international relations, this is a good way to do it. There are a LOT of assigned readings and needing to skim some is inevitable, but if you put in the time to do so it's not too difficult of a class.
Yes! If youre EPE and looking to fulfill a requirement, very interesting! Reading is not entirely necessary so work load is very manageable.
Yes. Professor Scheve was very engaging and the reading material was always interesting.
Yes, it was an incredibly accessible introduction to complex topics such as international relations.
Yes, if you are interested in international issues and politics
Yes.
Yes, I would strongly recommend this course to any student that would like an introduction to global politics with regard to trade and war.
yes
Yes, would absolutely recommend this course to anyone looking to better understand the basics of international relations.
If its required for your major. Otherwise, take more interesting stuff.

Yes - this may not have been the most engaging class I took this year, but given that I intend to take more classes in poli sci and global affairs, I think this course provides really helpful vocabulary to understand international conflict and negotiation and stuff that will be back in my academic career, so I feel as though this course has helped me to be ready for those future classes and the work I will eventually be doing.
Yes! teaches you the fundamentals of international relations
Yes. It is a great course that will give you a little insight to the poli sci major.

I would: the course contained interesting information and knowledge that could be very easily applicable to other fields, and it is taught very well. There isn't an excessive amount of reading, and the teaching staff typically highlighted which readings were most important and helpful.
Yes, especially for non-political science majors.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Recorded lecture
live (recorded) lecture with zoom discussion sections
Lectures were recorded, live virtual discussion sections
Combination of live lectures that were also recorded
Live lectures (also recorded for those students who couldn't attend) and weekly live virtual discussion sections.
live virtual section
The live virtual lectures were also recorded for later viewing.
NA
Live lecture that was recorded and weekly virtual discussion section
The lectures were also recorded and we also had sections on zoom.
Live virtual lecture+Recorded lecture
Virtual section, recorded lectures
there was also a section that had a seminar format!
Recorded lecture (2x per week) plus a weekly discussion section with the TF. Both periods were 50 min, although section often went over time.
Live virtual lectures that were recorded
I attended live virtual lectures and live virtual sections.
Live and recorded lectures
Recorded lecture
break-out rooms
Virtual lecture + discussion sections
recorded lecture
Live virtual discussion section
This had a live virtual lecture that was recorded, as well as an in-person section that was more in line with a virtual seminar.
Sections
live, recorded lecture & weekly discussion sections
discussion section
N/A
virtual live lecture, virtual live section
